title: 107_hr4193
content: The "Crackdown on Deadbeat Dealers Act of 2002" aims to address the issue of a small number of licensed firearms dealers contributing significantly to crime guns. The Act increases the number of allowed compliance inspections of firearms dealers and enhances penalties on gun kingpins. SEC. 4 of the "Crackdown on Deadbeat Dealers Act of 2002" increases penalties for engaging in illegal firearms business and calls for sentencing guideline enhancements. SEC. 5 addresses serious recordkeeping offenses aiding gun trafficking. SEC. 5 amends Section 924(a)(3) of title 18, imposing fines and imprisonment for serious recordkeeping offenses related to gun trafficking. SEC. 6 introduces suspension of firearms dealer's license and civil penalties for violations of the Gun Control Act. Subsections (e) and (f) of section 923 of title 18, United States Code, are amended to allow the Secretary to suspend or revoke licenses for willful violations of gun control laws or failure to provide secure gun storage. Civil penalties of up to $10,000 per violation may be imposed. Additionally, dealers who willfully transfer armor-piercing ammunition may have their licenses revoked or face civil penalties. The Secretary has the authority to compromise, mitigate, or remit liability for willful violations of gun control laws. Any denial, suspension, or revocation of a license, or assessment of a civil penalty, must be accompanied by a written notice stating the specific grounds. The aggrieved party has the right to request a hearing to review the decision. The Secretary can stay the suspension or revocation of a license upon request. A hearing will be held at a convenient location for the aggrieved party. If the Secretary upholds the decision after a hearing, the aggrieved party can file a petition for judicial review within 60 days. The court can consider new evidence in the review process. The court can order the Secretary to comply with its judgment regarding the denial, suspension, revocation, or civil penalty of a license. SEC. 7. TERMINATION OF FIREARMS DEALER'S LICENSE UPON FELONY CONVICTION. Amends Section 925(b) of title 18, United States Code to change the wording regarding the termination of a firearms dealer's license upon felony conviction.
